text: Did you not see what happened? Their attempt to overcome humanity's downfall was what created the monster Wau. The comet destroying the surface forced humanity to retreat to the ocean for survival resources. What the Wau is doing is creating its rendition of humans, but what it's making doesn't seem human to us, so in the end... did humanity end because what we recognize as humans no longer exist? or did humanity actually overcome extinction if the Wau continued to exist and create its version of humanity.

text: ¬†@Zidana123¬† he's not the only robot there. There was a lot of NPCs. My point is that even on a completely chaotic world, humans strive for order, structure and etc. They would start building something resembling a society. Somehow. I think a YouTuber reviewing this game said something similar. Don't recall who.
author: @ŒñŒÆŒΩœâŒΩ-Œ∂1Œπ
@Zidana123

text: ¬†@Zidana123¬† you're seeing this with the game horror logic and plot, which is fine. But looking at it realistically, these "post humans" wouldn't even be in this state to begin with. Even if initially they were to fall into that, they would eventually reject it. That's what I mean. "omg everything is meaningless and chaotic and there's no hope, I'm just gonna go mad and die". Unrealistic. On a chaotic world, humans strive for order and structure, which requires meaning and action, which men are more than happy and willing to create and act upon. They would naturally reject the hopelessly presented by the game's story. That's my point.  It's a good story and it brings up cool questions, and of course there would be no game without the existential horror so it's fine.

text:
I absolutely loved this game and the questions and dilemmas it brought up.
I had a conversation with a friend once and he told me about a scenario. 

Imagine a scientist creates a perfect cloning machine that makes a perfect copy of you. He goes into the little pod to scan himself and get a clone of himself. But at the end of the process his pod malfunctions and the man who made the machine dies. But his clone lives on.

What does this mean for the scientist? Is he really dead? Because his clone has all his previous memories and experiences and thoughts. So is the scientist really dead? And is it okay for the clone to take over his life? Are they not the same person?


 SOMA gave me the same questions to think about. Kudos to the creator for making this. It really makes you question existence and what it means to be alive.

text:
Earth was also very much subject to solar flares or stray rocks hitting it (and, well, look what happens). The ARK is literally running on borrowed time and all the people on it wanted to do was buy a seat into heaven. Such is life in space.

If it's any consolation, it looks like (based on the screen in the room with Sarah) the ARK runs a bit faster than real time so they can live centuries while days pass in reality. More than likely, in about 25 years when the ARK reaches the edge of our solar system, it can no longer draw enough energy from the Sun, it'll just go dark forever.

text:
Or worse, what if the scientist doesn't die so now there is two of him. Does the clone have the same rights as the original? Can he claim the ownership possessions of the original? Truly disturbing questions. It is why I love discussing this game. It really gets the player thinking.

text: I am actually of the opinion that they are in fact two different entities but that's because of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. The principal states that you can't persist or observe the state of matter because of constant unpredictable change. The two of you will have different molecular activity in your brain, and we don't know about how entropy impacts personality. You can think, behave, even act the same - but the guarantee can never be made you are functionally similar. You just have to hope the duplicate will behave consistently to the original.

text:
Oh god that was a damn wild ride. The ending's pretty disturbing to think about.










when you do think about it though, there is no such thing as a "coin toss" is there? It's not a 50/50 where you'll end up, it's just you copy and pasting your own consciousness into another body. Not to mention your next "incarnations" are not real people, they're just lines of code acting as a "you". Simon is long dead, Simon #2, #3, and ARK-Simon are just false copies of a person that thinks they're real. Same goes with the other ones.

author: @kapeecoffee

text: Like others have said, the whole "coin toss" thing isn't how it works even on a philosophical level. In order for it to be a coin toss there has to be a chance of a transfer, which there isn't. It's a copy, not a transfer. The original will always be the original and the copy will always be the copy. Just like when you run a paper through a copy machine. At no point is there a chance that the paper you're copying will somehow magically turn into the copy. They become separate entities the moment that the copying process is completed and their experiences start to diverge. That's why Simon and Catherine were never getting on the ARK. They were getting a version of themselves onto the ARK, but they were always going to remain behind no matter what. Simon just failed to realize that. Though to his credit, he did suffer from literal physical brain damage following a car crash, so i think we can cut him some slack. I guess Catherine was a bit slimy to keep stringing him along even after noticing that he wasn't catching on, but in her defense telling him the truth migh have meant that he would refuse to help her get the ARK into space, so i personally think she was at least partially justified. Plus if you go through all the audio and text logs you can tell she has trouble getting along with people, so it probably wasn't easy for her either.

author: @TheRealestEric

text:
¬†@Fraggr92¬† I think the coin flip idea is philosophically solid from the right perspective. The "chance" comes not from a possibility of the original somehow becoming the copy on the ARK, but from the somewhat abstract question of "Why am I me?". The Simon on the Ark is "lucky" to be the one of the two experiencing the Ark. It just gets weird because both results of the coin flip occur, and the only thing differentiating the two Simons is their respective result.

But I think its validity is dependent upon one's feelings about the question "Is a perfect copy of you still you?". If you somehow learned that every time you went to sleep and woke up that the consciousness that woke up was a copy of the one that went to sleep, would you still carry on as normal or lament the fact that you are going to die at the end of the day? 

If a person who feels that the copy is a continuation of the original rather than being a totally separate entity were in Simon's situation and wanted to get onto the ARK, the coin flip model makes sense. Even if they're only self-interested and care nothing for the other copy post-divergence, they would still be motivated to reach the ARK because, from their perspective, there's a 50% chance that they'll be satisfied with the result.

text:
Err no your understanding of the story is way, way off. It is probably why you didn't feel impacted by the story.  Can't blame you though since Gura did miss a lot of important lore stuff.

Ok what happened is the WAU already existed before the comet's impact, and its main function was to control the life support systems of the base. After the comet hit and wiped out all life on the surface, the WAU changed its directives from maintaining the base to "preserving humanity". There was no virus or anything involved. 

But since the WAU is a machine which doesn't have a clear definition of what humanity actually is, it starts doing all kinds of crazy things in order to  follow its warped directive of "preserving humanity", like scanning people's minds and stuffing them into robots, reanimating dead human bodies, keeping people alive on invasive life support, or putting people in a Matrix-like dreamstate while their body is left comatose.


The ARK project was initially a pet project by Catherine, but after the comet hit the survivors thought it was the best way of ensuring that at least some remnant of humanity can survive. Interestingly enough. Catherine actually reversed-engineered some of the WAU's innovations to develop the ARK technology, but otherwise the ARK has nothing to do with the WAU. The reason why they wanted to get the ARK away from the WAU is because they didn't want the WAU to corrupt the brain scans inside. The ARK was never meant to stop the WAU or anything.

When Simon got his brain scanned first in the prologue, it was nearly 100 years before the main story. The reason Simon shows up on the base in a robot body is because original Simon from 100 years ago let his brain scan be saved and people started using his legacy scan as an extremely common and available foundation for AI development. And since his brain scans were so easily available, the WAU had no trouble accessing it and transferring his brain scan into a robot as part of its "preserve humanity" directive. 

As the player, Simon later finds out that he was not magically teleported into the future, but rather his memories and experiences were copied into a robot and that his original self died nearly a century ago. In any case, Simon launches the ARK into space, but it is a bittersweet ending because for all of Simon's efforts, it doesn't change the fact that humanity is still extinct.

text:
¬†@DarkAdonisVyers¬† suprisingly topical, Kurzgetsatz just made a video on that topic (sort of).

Basically, we don't really know exactly how the brain works. and there's many theories on what makes a human mind. Soma doesn't say that a "soul" can be capture as data, because according to what Soma presents, there's no such thing as a "soul". A person's consciousness is entirely composed of their past experiences and the way their brain is wired. So when your brained is scanned and copied, it creates a second person with its own separate consciousness. I recommend watching Kurzgetsatz's video if you want a better explanation.

I haven't played KH2, but I assume it would mean that someone's consciousness isn't just their brain and how it functions, but has something extra (a "soul"), so just copying the brain wouldn't be able to make a new person (or something along thoses lines, idk I haven't played the game and only basing myself on that one line you said)


We currently don't have a definitive answer as far as I know, so it's mostly a matter of belief for now. I personally think Soma's approach to be correct, but we don't have any proof of that.

author: @juliogomesdesouza9035

text:
¬†@juliogomesdesouza9035¬† Well it is a bit hard for me to put it into words but the so-called coin toss is just an illusion of chance. In reality the original is never going to get transferred, while the copy will always end up transferring. In other words, there is no coin toss since everything is already pre-determined.

Since the copy inherits all the memories and thoughts of the original, one could say that prior to the coin toss, Simon 3 and Simon 4 are basically the same entity. And Simon 3 and Simon 4 have no way of knowing which Simon they are until they actually perform the coin toss. From Simon 4's perspective, he won the toss while from Simon 3's perspective, he lost. From their perspective it looks like there was a coin toss when in actuality there was none. The coin toss is just them finding out who is the per-determined winner or loser.

Hence why Simon 3 will always fail to get onto the ARK while Simon 4 will always succeed. 

TL;DR: There is no coin toss, just the perception of one, because a true coin toss implies chance but there is no chance involved when transferring. Everything has been determined from the start.

I doubt that is a good enough explanation but I tried lol.

Hey hey... The ending of this game was rather predictable, and here I'll post a comment about it to torture your pitiful souls kekekek spoilers btw.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
. 
. 
. 
. 
Okay, so, they launched the ark to outer space, and everyone took it as a happy ending somewhat, BUT, when the ark runs out of power, or if something crashes it, the ones inside will die the in the most despairing way possible, because they won't be able to resist in any way since that thing is isolated from reality... So it was only a very delayed death sentence...

On further notes, copying and pasting works the same way as cut and paste, or move, you pick the original data copy it and paste it, the difference with the latter 2 is that there's an extra, automatic deletion step, so it gives the illusion of the data being moved, but it wasn't... So you don't need to feel bad about the "moral" choices on the game, aside from the last one that was actually mercy, since she would've died anyway...

And now, probably consciousness "data" wouldn't probably work that way, since the way it works kinda makes it impossible to copy, maybe it'll need to be transferred, but literally transferred, not like normal bit data of 0's and 1's, so the premise it's a bit crooked, so don't feel so bad gura~ lol

text: ¬†@open_your_third_eye4699¬† Oh, alright. Thanks for telling me, i guess its a possibility. If true then the ending is even darker then i originally thought, since if her chip has fried then there's no way for Simon to get her back online. And he truly is alone, forever, especially if he killed the WAU, the other simon, amy and every optional robot. I always imagined the WAU would start creating more successful copies after making simon. But im just rambling at this point...
author: @Orome96

text:
¬†@Orome96¬† I agree, it makes it even more hopeless of a situation for Simon. But I guess that's exactly what they intended, so it works out in the story's favor.

As for the WAU creating more copies of him: For all we know, it might have. Or perhaps it created others the same way before shutting down. The question is, even if Simon found them, what would be the point? The ark is launched, his only way off this hell on earth is gone. All his hopes gone with it. I personally don't think Simon would have any motivation left at that point anyway. But that's just speculation on my part now ^^ 

In any case, I think the game does an excellent job of giving the player that feeling of despair Simon must feel in that moment, and ending it right there only makes it so much worse, since it leaves it to one's imagination.

author: @YataTheFifteenth

text:
They believed in an ontological concept they called "Continuity"
It goes something like:
At the point of brain scanning, there are two identical consciousnesses, with identical sets of memories and experiences. These two consciousnesses are effectively one identical individual which exists in two locations (in the chair and on the Ark). However, if both continue to exist going forward, then they will gain new memories and experiences from the point of scanning and diverge into two unique individuals. If one of the consciousnesses (the one in the chair) is killed at that moment, however, the individual consciousness is forced into the one remaining location (on the Ark)
author: @Zidana123

text: ¬†@Zidana123¬† the term ‚Äúcontinuity‚Äù is a term for writing stories. A story has good continuity when everything is internally consistent, with no contradictions. The story they told themselves was, ‚ÄúIf we scan our brains into the Ark, we can escape into space and survive the apocalypse, living in blissful VR heaven.‚Äù This story kept their hope alive in the final days of humanity, allowing the scientists to put their full minds to their task. Unfortunately, there was a continuity error in their story. When they were scanned in, all they did was create a functionally identical copy of their minds, while they themselves would remain. Their story did not have continuity. To fix the continuity, they unmade themselves, choosing to believe that they had passed into the ark, but all it was was a happy fiction.
